questions.question: An elderly male is identified to have a well-circumscribed lesion within the prostate suspicious of cancer. Based on the McNeal classification, in which prostatic zone is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Peripheral Zone Explanation: The majority of prostate cancers originate in the peripheral zone according to McNeal’s Zonal classification of the prostate. Anatomy of prostate: Location : Immediately inferior to the bladder. It surrounds the first 3 cm of the urethra. Capsules: True capsule: Fibrous capsule formed by the condensation of the peripheral part of the gland. False capsule: Visceral layer of pelvic fascia. Prostatic venous plexus are embedded in it on either side. Anatomical lobes (5 lobes): Anterior and posterior lobes; two lateral lobes; and one median lobe. McNeal Zonal classification of prostate gland: Peripheral zone: most common site for carcinoma. (Option B) Periurethral transition zone: most common site for BPH. (Option A ruled out) Central zone: surrounds the ejaculatory ducts. (Option C ruled out) Anterior Fibromuscular Stroma : Non-glandular area, and surrounds an inferior portion of the prostate called the apex (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A 75-year-old man presents with difficulty in urination, weak stream, and increased frequency. On digital rectal examination, his prostate is found to be enlarged, and his PSA levels are mildly elevated. Which enzyme converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, a hormone responsible for the pathogenesis of his condition? β Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase I reductase
questions.explanation: I reductase Correct Answer: C) 5 I reductase Explanation: The patient likely has benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) . Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is the androgen that stimulates prostate growth . 5- α reductase is the enzyme that converts testosterone into DHT , making it central to BPH pathogenesis. Inhibitors of 5- α reductase (e.g., finasteride, dutasteride) are used in treatment. Testosterone Metabolism & BPH Enzyme Function 5- α Reductase Converts testosterone to DHT → promotes prostate growth Aromatase Converts androgens to estrogens 17- β Hydroxysteroid DH Converts androstenedione ↔ testosterone; not involved in DHT production 21-Hydroxylase Involved in cortisol/aldosterone synthesis, not androgen pathway Aromatase (Option A): Incorrect. Converts testosterone to estradiol, not involved in DHT production. 17- β Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (Option B): Incorrect. Helps convert androstenedione to testosterone but not to DHT . 21-Hydroxylase (Option D): Incorrect. Important in cortisol and aldosterone synthesis, unrelated to androgens or BPH . Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1522, 1523 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1033, 1034 Campbell Walsh Wein Urology, 12th Edition, Page 15091 Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 494-497

questions.question: A 68-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary frequency, nocturia, and a weak urinary stream. The International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) assessment reveals a score of 22. Which of the following best describes the severity of his symptoms according to the IPSS?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Severe Explanation: A score of 20 to 35 is severely symptomatic according to the International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS). International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS): Subjective assessment tool for BPH patients The questionnaire assesses the degree of LUTS and quality of life. SCORE : Mildly symptomatic: 0 to 7 (Option A ruled out) Moderately symptomatic: 8 to 19 (Option B ruled out) Severely symptomatic: 20 to 35 (Option C ) The mnemonic " FUN WISE " can be used to remember the seven questions relating to symptoms of BPH in the IPSS questionnaire. F Frequency U Urgency N Nocturia W Weak stream I Intermittency S Straining E Sensation of incomplete emptying The symptoms must have been experienced in the last month and each answer is scored from 0 to 5 for a maximum score of 35 points. Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/international-prostate-symptom-score https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10196226/

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with urinary frequency, nocturia, and a weak urinary stream for 6 months. His prostate is symmetrically enlarged, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is slightly elevated and Qmax (Uroflowmetry) is 7 ml/sec. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tamsulosin Explanation: In this scenario, based on clinical symptoms, signs, and Qmax value he is suffering from BPH, and the initial management is Tamsulosin ( I 1 Blocker) . Investigations in BPH: Urine microscopy and C/S. Ultrasound abdomen- residual urine and prostate size. Uroflowmetry (Qmax): Normal: > 15 ml/sec. Equivocal: 10-15 ml. Low: <10 ml Cystometry: Voiding pressure Normal: <60 cm of H I O Equivocal: 60- 80 cm of H I O High: >80 cm of H I O Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) Treatment: Medical management: 1st line management: I 1 Blocker Prazosin Terazosin Silodosin Most commonly used: Tamsulosin ( I 1A selective Blocker) (Option B) 2nd line: 5 I Reductase inhibitors Finasteride (Option D ruled out) Dutasteride Triptorelin pamoate Combination treatment with I 1 Blocker and 5 I Reductase inhibitors are used in large prostate Acute management in urinary retention: urethral catheterization (Option C ruled out) and if it fails - suprapubic cystostomy (SPC). Surgical management: Indications: No improvement in medical management. Acute retention of urine Chronic urinary retention with residual urine of more than 200 ml. Complications like hydroureter, hydronephrosis, stone formation, recurrent infection, and gross haematuria Surgeries: Gold standard- TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate). (Option A ruled out) Trans urethral incision of prostate (TUIP) Open prostatectomy procedures Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1526-1529

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common complication of TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Retrograde ejaculation Explanation: The most common complication of TURP procedure is retrograde ejaculation (75% of the cases) due to disruption to the bladder-neck mechanism. TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate): Cutting is performed by a high-frequency diathermy current Strips of tissue are cut from the bladder neck down to the level of the verumontanum Monopolar TURP Bipolar TURP Irrigant 1% glycine Normal saline Time for resection Limited Extended Quality of hemostasis Poor Good Energy/ voltage/ thermal effect High Low After TURP, a three-way, self-retaining catheter is inserted and the bladder is irrigated with isotonic saline to prevent any further bleeding from forming blood clots. Complications of TURP: Local complications: Hemorrhage, perforation of bladder, prostatic capsule perforation Sepsis- Bacteraemia Incontinence- rare complication (Option C ruled out) Retrograde ejaculation- most common (>75% cases) (Option A) Erectile dysfunction- rare (Option D ruled out) Urethral stricture Bladder neck contracture- occasionally General complications: Cardiovascular Pulmonary atelectasis, pneumonia, myocardial infarction, congestive cardiac failure, and deep venous thrombosis TURP syndrome - less common with the use of isotonic glycine and saline as irrigants (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: A 70-year-old man is undergoing transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia. Postoperatively, he gets agitated and complains of severe headache, nausea, and blurred vision. His lab results show a serum sodium level of 118 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Administer intravenous hypertonic saline Explanation: In this scenario, the patient suffers from TURP syndrome, and hypertonic saline 3% is used cautiously in severe or symptomatic cases . TURP Syndrome (Dilutional hyponatremia): Pathophysiology: Fluid is absorbed intravascularly due to high volumes of hypotonic irrigation fluid used during the resection causing dilutional hyponatremia and various neurologic symptoms. Risk factors: Size of prostate > 75g Duration of surgery > 90 minutes Pre-existing hyponatremia Renal failure Clinical features: Confusion, agitation, nervousness, nausea, hemolysis, visual disturbances, coma, and shock. Treatment: Drug of choice- IV furosemide. Mild to moderate cases: IV furosemide (Option B ruled out) and normal saline (Option C ruled out) Severe or symptomatic patients: IV 3% Saline (Option A) Fluid restriction (Option D ruled out) : Useful after initial stabilization and correction of severe hyponatremia to prevent further fluid overload. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560884/ Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1530

questions.question: A 65-year-old male is undergoing surgery for Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia with distressing LUTS (lower urinary tract symptoms). Prostate gland is significantly enlarged, measuring over 100 grams. Which among the following surgical approach is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Open prostatectomy Explanation: Open prostatectomy is the preferred approach in cases where the prostate size is more than 75 grams. Open prostatectomy (Option B) : Indications: Size of prostate: > 75 grams Bladder stone Bladder diverticula Transurethral Incision of Prostate (Option A ruled out) : Procedure: An electrocautery device (Collin’s knife) or laser is used to incise the prostate tissue from the bladder neck down to the verumontanum. Size of prostate: up to 30 grams Advantages: Less time consuming Lower risk of impotence and retrograde ejaculation Frayer’s suprapubic prostatectomy (Option C ruled out) : Indication: Bladder stone and bladder diverticula along with BPH. Young’s perineal prostatectomy (Option D ruled out) : Obsolete procedure. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1283025/ https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/transurethral-incision-of-the-prostate https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37794546/ SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1035 Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1528, 1529 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3921814/

questions.question: A 55-year-old male, known diabetic presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever, perineal pain, and difficulty urinating. He has a history of acute bacterial prostatitis, treated two weeks ago with antibiotics. On examination, the prostate is tender and swollen. What is the most likely diagnosis and investigation to confirm the same?

options.D: Benign prostatic hyperplasia and PSA levels

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prostatic abscess and Transrectal ultrasound Explanation: Acute bacterial prostatitis can develop into a prostate abscess if the initial infection is not adequately treated or if the patient has comorbidities like diabetes as in this case. Persistent fever, perineal pain, and a tender, swollen prostate on examination raise suspicion of prostate abscess. A transrectal ultrasound or CT pelvis is needed to evaluate and manage the condition. Condition Acute bacterial prostatitis (Option C ruled out) Chronic bacterial prostatitis (Option B ruled out) Prostatic abscess (Option A) Etiopathogenesis Acute inflammation of prostate. Risk factor- STI, prolonged catheterization and instrumentation. Gram-negative bacteria, enterobacteriaceae Common organism- E. coli Development of bacterial biofilms. Enterobacteriaceae Common organism- E. coli Complication of acute bacterial prostatitis High risk: Immunocompromised people Diabetes Chronic catheterization Clinical features Fever, chills, rigor Back pain Perineal pain/ heaviness Pain on defecation Associated UTI symptoms DRE: Tender, enlarged Persistent infection of prostate and recurrent attacks of UTI Fever, chills, rigor Back pain Perineal pain/ heaviness DRE: Tender, swollen prostate, positive fluctuation Investigation Urine routine and culture Transrectal US and CT pelvis to rule out abscess in high-risk patients Microscopy and culture of prostatic expresate and urine taken before and prostatic massage Transrectal US and CT pelvis Treatment Prolonged antibiotics Trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin, or aminoglycoside for 4 to 6 weeks to prevent chronic prostatitis Antibiotics for 3-4 months based on culture. Trans urethral drainage IV Antibiotics Benign prostatic hyperplasia and PSA levels (Option D) : It is a non-malignant growth or hyperplasia of prostate tissue, commonly seen in elderly men. PSA levels are useful in assessing the extent of prostate enlargement and to monitor the condition over time. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459257/ Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1536, 1537, 1522, 1523.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male undergoes evaluation for a urinary tract infection. Imaging studies reveal multiple small stones within the prostate gland. Laboratory analysis of these prostatic calculi will most likely show which of the following compositions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Calcium phosphate Explanation: Endogenous prostatic calculi are usually composed of calcium phosphate combined with about 20% organic material. Prostatic calculi: Two varieties: endogenous (common), and exogenous (urinary calculus that becomes arrested in the prostatic urethra) Composition: Calcium phosphate with about 20% organic material (Option D) Prostatic calculi are usually symptomless Doesn’t predispose to infection Investigation: Imaging- stones are often seen to form a horseshoe pattern . Occurs in clusters Treatment: Transurethral resection Forerunners of endogenous prostatic calculi are corpora amylacea. Uric acid (Option A) , struvite (Option B), and calcium oxalate (Option C) are not routinely found as endogenous prostatic calculi.

questions.question: An elderly male presents with urinary hesitancy, weak stream, nocturia, weight loss, and back pain. DRE reveals a hard, irregular prostate. Which of the following is the common genetic alteration observed in his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hypermethylation of GSTP1 Explanation: In this scenario, the most likely diagnosis is carcinoma prostate and the common genetic alteration seen in carcinoma prostate is hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located in chromosome 11. Carcinoma prostate: Most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years. Most common among Afro-American Risk factor: Advanced age High-fat diet Protective factors: (LESA) L ycopene Vitamin E S elenium Vitamin A Pathology: Most common site- peripheral zone (75%) > transitional zone (15%) > central zone (10%) Most common histological type is adenocarcinoma Most common genetic alteration seen in CA prostate- hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located on chromosome 11. (Option B) 70-80% of the cases. Microscopy: small, crowded, absent basal layer, lack of branching Clinical features: Commonly asymptomatic. Bladder outlet obstruction. Haematuria Pelvic pain, back pain, arthritic pain in sacroiliac joint-features of secondaries On per rectal examination: hard, nodular, irregular often with loss of median groove. Routes of spread: Most common route of spread- haematogenous (skeletal metastases: pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae) Other routes- local, lymphatic Mutation of the BRCA1 gene (Option A) : Men with BRCA2 mutations have an increased risk, but not the commonest genetic mutation for ca prostate. Overexpression of HER2 (Option C) : It is associated with breast cancer. Mutation of the RB1 gene (Option D) : It is associated with retinoblastoma. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 940, 941, 1531-1534 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563248/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4995330/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/5925

questions.question: A 70-year-old male presents with an elevated PSA level of 12 ng/mL. A transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy reveals a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

options.A: Active surveillance with regular PSA monitoring and repeat biopsies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hormone therapy and possibly radiation Explanation: A Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5) indicates a very high-grade and aggressive prostate cancer , likely to spread rapidly. The elevated PSA level and high Gleason score suggest advanced disease. Hormone therapy , which reduces or blocks testosterone, is a key treatment for advanced prostate cancer. Radiation therapy may also be considered to control local disease . Investigation Key Points DRE Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage PSA Test Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer TRUS Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities mpMRI Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread Prostate Biopsy Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells Gleason Score Purpose: Predicts cancer aggressiveness and potential for spread. Important for prognosis and treatment planning. Scoring System: Ranges from 6 to 10, based on gland appearance and differentiation. Two most common patterns in the biopsy are graded and summed for the final score. Gleason Score Grade Components Cancer Grade Description 6 3 + 3 Low-grade Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread. 7 3 + 4 or 4 + 3 Intermediate-grade Cells show more variation; moderate risk of growth and spread. 8 4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3 High-grade Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread. 9 or 10 4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5 Very high-grade Cells are highly aggressive; very likely to grow and spread quickly. CA Prostate Management: Management Strategy Key Points Active Surveillance (Option A ruled out) For low-risk cases; regular monitoring Radical Prostatectomy (Option B ruled out) Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative Radiation Therapy High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy Hormone Therapy (Option C) Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases Chemotherapy Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases Observation with no immediate treatment (Option D ): is inappropriate for aggressive, high-grade cancers like a Gleason score of 9, where immediate treatment is necessary. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1451 , 1533-1536

questions.question: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia. During the procedure, a tumor is discovered, which involves less than 5% of the resected tissue and is well-differentiated. The tumor was an incidental finding and was not palpable during a digital rectal examination. Based on the TNM staging system for prostate cancer, what is the most appropriate stage for this tumor?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) T1a Explanation: T1a stage indicates that the tumor was found incidentally during a procedure like TURP and involves less than 5% of the resected tissue. The tumor is usually well-differentiated. TNM Staging System for Prostate Cancer T1 : Incidentally found tumors in a clinically benign gland. T1a : Tumor involves <5% of the resected specimen. (Option A) T1b : Tumor involves >5% of the resected specimen. (Option B ruled out) T1c : Impalpable tumor found due to raised PSA. T2 : Tumor confined within the prostate capsule. T2a : Involves one lobe. (Option C ruled out) T2b : Involves more than half of one side but not both sides. T2c : Involves both sides, confined within the capsule. T3 : Tumor extends through the capsule. T3a : Unilateral or bilateral extension. (Option D ruled out) T3b : Extension into seminal vesicles. T4 : Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum, pelvic sidewall). N0 : No regional lymph node involvement N1 : Regional lymph node involvement M0 : No distant metastasis M1 : Distant metastasis present Additional Staging Factors Gleason Score : Grading system based on cancer cell resemblance to healthy tissue. PSA Level : Blood test measuring prostate-specific antigen; elevated levels may indicate prostate cancer. Imaging Tests : MRI and bone scans used to detect cancer spread. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1532-1535
